list.item: Aunt Lydia Whaley & her willows for baskets
Men from Delco Light System visit us to make estimate

p.del: has been on the job a long time. Thank you for the papers.
It seems so funny to think of Jane working & pa home - it's surely a change for you both!

div1.p:
My last was written Wednesday - started it in the a.m. & then finished it that night - Well - after school Thursday - we girls - Abbey Emily & I went to Aunt Lydia's after some baskets. It was a perfectly beautiful day warm & bright (have been wearing my lovely sweater & cap on walks lately as it's been so nice) and we had a very nice call & came
home loaded with baskets.

I sent Lida $18's worth Friday - and told her to bring to you what she couldn't sell among the girls - Jane - The money goes to Mrs. Richardson whose name is on the bill. Aunt Lydia has a number of willows growing on the bank of the "branch" just outside her cabin door that she trims for making the baskets - "golden willow" she calls it & just the color of gold too.

Friday was the debate on suffrage - the whole community is against I guess - Several of those who were to take the part wouldn't the last minute - but managed to fill in their
as we had discussed it quite thoroughly in school that afternoon. The negative side was given the decision of course -

We were glad when the drill by my girls was over & could come home - S. Two men representing the Delco - Light System were there here whom Miss Langmaid had asked to come up way before Xmas. They went over things that night - showed their illustrations etc. & the next morning went over the place & will send in an estimate soon - it will be nearly $2000 including everything but the fixtures - all the buildings & the grounds lighted. However it's not definitely decided yet.

Saturday morning was busy as usual & in the p.m. went up to the Forks of the River with Cora Ogle - Lucrettie Reagan & her mother. The girls were going to stay for a sing that evening - but Martha Reagan & I just called at Ollie Carr's (one of my girls) & then came back & stopped & made another call on Hattie - Charlie Ogle's wife - who is a Maples - the oldest daughter of Squire Maples where we stayed for dinner last Sunday.
Dr. Massy was here for dinner & stayed all night making a pleasant break in things. He is dabbling in lumber and has made a good deal of lumber money this springfall & winter I guess -

As this was church Sunday we put in the three hour usual
session - Poor Evelyn went overstayed three hours yesterday afternoon. (Guess I'm getting sleepy - have made so many mistakes!) After dinner I dashed off some letters and did some reading - Then three of the little girls - who dropped in - Evelyn & I went updown the road to meet the girls as they drove back - Next was supper followed by B.Y. & then we sat around the fire a little while before coming upstairs. The light went out at church tonight & finally the two lamps - so that we
had to send for our two faithful Rochesters to finish things. So endeth this day!
With much love to you all as always - Ruth.
